none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Charles Puryear, June 30, 1890

body.value:
Box 183,
Richmond, Virginia,
30 June 1890

Prof. L. L. McInnis,
College Station, Texas;

My dear Sir:

Until today, I had
had only a meagre account
of what had transpired at
the College since I left.
I beg to assure you that I
am very sorry to learn
the outcome, both in your
own account and for the

**Analysis and Transcription of Handwritten Letter**

Okay, so I've got this handwritten letter in front of me. The first thing I'm doing is breaking down the image. I'm noting the standard letter format here, starting with the header: "Box 183," "Richmond, Virginia," and the date "30 June 1890." Now the recipient's information: "Prof. L. L. Mc<sup>c</sup>Innis," at "College Station, Texas." The letter is addressed with the standard salutation "My dear Sir:".

The initial part of the letter reads: "Until today, I had had only a meagre account of what had transpired at the College since I left." This is straightforward enough. Now I'm getting into the meat of it. The next part is tricky, specifically that one word. It's, "I beg to assure you that I am very sorry to [verb] the outcome, both in your own account and for the..."

I'm zeroing in on this uncertain word. It's starts with a loop and appears to be 'l-e-a-r-n'. Looking closely at the "e", the "a", the "r", the "n", it all matches what I expect. I'm comparing it to other words in the letter such as "left" to confirm. I'm confident in "learn" now, and the context supports this. So the sentence reads: "I beg to assure you that I am very sorry to learn the outcome, both in your own account and for the…"

Now I need to deal with formatting the text. I'm using HTML tags as requested. The dates, recipients and salutations are all standard. I think the rest is simple. I can clearly see all the words I need: "meagre," "transpired," "College," "outcome," "in," "account." Everything is clean. I need to note that "M<sup>c</sup>Innis" is correct with the raised "c". I will transcribe it accordingly. Also "in" with the dot above makes that clear as well.

I feel confident in my transcription. Time to output the final text.

best interest of the College.
I inferred from my first in-
formation that your connect-
ion was entirely severed.
At any rate I can appreciate
the fact that, under the cir-
cumstances, your first impulse
would be seek another field.
I hope you will not consider
it presumption on my part
to suggest that, if at all practicable,
you remain at the College as
Professor and possibly matters
will take another turn ere
long. I have no idea what

**Final Thoughts Before Transcription** Alright, let's get down to brass tacks. I've got the image of the handwritten letter in front of me, and my mission is to extract the text as accurately as humanly possible. I'm going to approach this meticulously, line by line, wrestling with every cursive flourish and faded ink stroke. My goal is precision; I don't want to add my own interpretation or guess at what's intended. First, I assessed the overall impression: the handwriting is cursive, slanted, and the paper is creased, so this tells me the letter probably isn't very recent. The ink is faded but mostly legible, which is good. I'm starting at the top, line by line. I initially read "best interests of the College," then immediately second-guessed the "interests" part. Looking closer, it's singular - "interest" - with the "s" either missing or just a tiny flick. Definitely singular. Got it. Now, onwards. As I work my way down, I'm carefully transcribing each word, and immediately cross-checking. I run into a tricky bit with "would be seek" in line 8. It's grammatically odd. I'm trying to decide if it's a missing "to," a strange stroke of "seek," or a writer's error. I'm going back and forth, comparing "seek" to "severed" to ensure I'm reading the letters correctly. There's a tiny mark between "be" and "seek" but it doesn't look like "to". I've decided to transcribe exactly what is written, as "would be seek". The lack of a "to" is incorrect, but that is what is written. I'm doing a double-take at the word "turn" in line 14. It's a bit messy. The letters don't seem clear. I'm trying "take another turn", it's what makes the most sense. I'm carefully comparing the 't' in this word and comparing it to other 't' in the text. I'm also looking for a cross on the 't'. Then the second letter is a mystery. Is it "time", "turn", "line", "hue"? "take another hue" makes sense, and "take another line" makes sense, but given the rest of the letter, "take another turn" makes the most sense. That would also mean that the author is probably intending a change to happen "ere long". It is an older expression, but the meaning is clear: "before long". I'm now going back over the text one last time, checking for any inconsistencies, particularly with capitalization, and making sure the final transcription precisely mirrors the original. I'm paying extra attention to the grammar: "best interest", and "would be seek". Ready. Here's the result: ```html

will be done at the meeting
this week towards securing a
chairman or Prest. I have often
expressed the opinion that I should
not like to see any one then at
the College occupying that position
except yourself and I hope
now that they will go outside.
I am sorry to see the evidence
of so much influence in a
certain quarter there and I
do not think it forebodes an
increase of harmony.
I would cheerfully have
waited at the College
for the action of the Board

**Transcription Summary** Alright, let's break this down. My primary goal here is to get an accurate transcription of this handwritten document. The text, obviously a letter, is in cursive, and it's generally readable, but there are a few quirks and areas that demand close attention. I'm going to take this step-by-step, meticulously going through each line. Line 1 seems straightforward enough: "will be done at the meeting." No issues there. Line 2: "this week towards securing a" - "towards" looks a little scrawled, but it's clearly "towards". No major difficulties. Line 3: "chairman or Prest I have often" - "chairman" is a safe bet, and "I have often" is simple. But "Prest" — that's the one. It looks like "Prest" with a dot, very likely a standard abbreviation for President ("Pres."). It could also be a "!" but is more probably a "." Let's stick with that. Line 4: "expressed the opinion that I should" - All good. Legible and direct. Line 5: Now, this is where it gets interesting. "not like to see any one [word] at". The question is the mysterious word in the middle. It looks like it is either "then" or "there" or "them". It could also be some other words. The most likely is "then", but it could also be "there" or even "them". Given the context, I think "then" makes the most sense. Line 6: "the College occupying that position". Clear and straightforward. Line 7: "except yourself and I hope" - Easy. Line 8: "now that they will go outside." Okay, a period, simple. Line 9: "I am sorry to see the evidence" - No issues. Line 10: "of so much influence in a" - No issues. Line 11: "certain quarter there and I" - The "there" is clear, and the "I" is uppercase. Line 12: "do not think it forebodes an" - "forebodes" is a slightly uncommon word, but the handwriting is clear enough to render it correctly. Line 13: "increase of harmony." Again, clear and straightforward, and a period. Line 14: "I would cheerfully have" - No issues. Line 15: "waited at the College" - Clear and easy. Line 16: "for the action of the Board" - It is written, so no issues here. I re-checked everything. Now, the transcription. I am happy with the transcription of the image.

had I seen any way
in which I could have
been of service to you but
with the lights before me
and without the knowledge
of any charges against you
I did not see anything
that I could do.

With kindest regards to Mrs.
McInnis and the little
girls and with best wishes,
I am,
Very truly your friend,
[Signature] Charles Puryear
1890
